p: Recruitment should remain at or above 0.103 to maintain stable to increasing population growth (λ ≥ 1; Figure 4). If the scenario of a solar cycle similar to the grand maximum with 500 ppm CO 2 occurs, recruitment may decline to 0.099 (95% CI = 0.071–0.120; Figure 4) and management intervention on the breeding grounds would likely have to result, on average, in an additional 0.5 juveniles per 100 adults to avoid population decline. To maintain long‐term average population growth (3.5%), recruitment should remain at or above 0.137 (Figure 4). The only scenario predicted to achieve this is 400 ppm CO 2 concentration during a solar cycle similar to the Dalton minimum (Figures 4 and 5). Other scenarios, such as a typical solar cycle or modern grand maximum with 500 ppm CO 2 concentration suggests average recruitment may decline to 0.108 (95% CI = 0.081–0.128) and 0.099 (95% CI = 0.071–0.120; Figure 4), respectively. Thus, any management intervention on the breeding grounds would likely have to result, on average, in an additional 3 to 4 juveniles recruited per 100 adults to maintain the long‐term population growth.
